Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation2: An operator keeps tweaking settings incorrectly, causing noticeable material waste.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to head to the factory floor. It was a text from my younger brother: “Can you call? I really need to talk.” He never reached out unless it was serious. I stared at the message, heart pounding, but the supervisor’s voice echoed from the workshop, “We need you at Line 3. The operator’s messing up the settings again.” I knew exactly who it was—Mr. Patel, always convinced he knew better, but his constant adjustments were wasting materials and time. Management expected me to step in, correct him, and explain—again—how to use the machine properly. But my brother’s words tugged at me. As his sister, I was supposed to be there, to listen and support him, especially when he was struggling. Yet, as the machine repairer, I was needed right now to prevent further losses and guide the operator. I stood frozen in the hallway, phone in hand, torn between the urgent needs of my family and my responsibility at work, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
